results.snippet: LEAD:  WEAPON by Robert Mason (Putnam, $18.95) has an unusual and amusing premise. Meet Solo, a $2 billion robot designed for the Army by a brilliant American. Solo is going to be the ultimate soldier. He is packed full of gadgetry that gives him...
results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: WEAPON by Robert Mason (Putnam, $18.95) has an unusual and amusing premise. Meet Solo, a $2 billion robot designed for the Army by a brilliant American. Solo is going to be the ultimate soldier. He is packed full of gadgetry that gives him amazing strength and speed. He reads codes, picks up transmissions from space satellites and has his own kind of intelligence.

headline.main: IN THE NATION: Houston; A Disney Creation for Visitors To the Johnson Space Center

results.snippet: LEAD: SINCE 1964, when what is now the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center was built on 1,600 acres of prairie land donated to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Rice University, the aerospace industry has been an integral part of...
results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: SINCE 1964, when what is now the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center was built on 1,600 acres of prairie land donated to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Rice University, the aerospace industry has been an integral part of Houston's identity as well as its economy.

headline.main: Astronaut's Jet Flies Very Close To an Airliner

results.snippet: LEAD: A jet training plane flown by the commander of the last space shuttle mission came within 500 feet of hitting a Pan American World Airways wide-body jet about 30 miles west of Washington on Monday evening, according to aviation officials.
results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: A jet training plane flown by the commander of the last space shuttle mission came within 500 feet of hitting a Pan American World Airways wide-body jet about 30 miles west of Washington on Monday evening, according to aviation officials.

results.snippet: LEAD: The space agency moved today to quickly fill vacancies in the management of the space station program, naming a former astronaut to head the program.

byline.original: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The space agency moved today to quickly fill vacancies in the management of the space station program, naming a former astronaut to head the program.

results.snippet: LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named a former astronaut, Dr. William B. Lenoir, to head the space station program. Dr. Lenoir, who flew a shuttle mission in 1982, is now a vice president of Booz-Allen & Hamilton, a...

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named a former astronaut, Dr. William B. Lenoir, to head the space station program. Dr. Lenoir, who flew a shuttle mission in 1982, is now a vice president of Booz-Allen & Hamilton, a consulting company. The space agency also announced that Richard Kohrs, the deputy manager of the space shuttle program at Johnson Space Center in Houston, will move to NASA's headquarters in Washington to be operational director for the space station, which is to be called Freedom.

results.snippet: LEAD: For Navy Capt. David M. Walker, the easy part was commanding the space shuttle Atlantis on a four-day flight around the earth earlier this month. The more hazardous part was getting to Washington from Houston last week for a Presidential...
results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For Navy Capt. David M. Walker, the easy part was commanding the space shuttle Atlantis on a four-day flight around the earth earlier this month. The more hazardous part was getting to Washington from Houston last week for a Presidential reception honoring the shuttle crew. About 30 miles west of Washington, aviation officials said, a jet training plane piloted by Captain Walker came within 500 feet of a Pan American World Airways wide-body jet carrying 176 people and bound for Paris, prompting the Pan Am pilot to report a ''near midair collision.

headline.main: Warsaw Journal; Communist Wallflowers Join Democracy's Dance

results.snippet: LEAD: The Communist Party's candidates held an open house Saturday, and they were selling warm Coca-Cola, toilet paper and biographies of President Bush.

byline.original: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

byline.original: By JANUSZ GLOWACKI; Janusz Glowacki, the author of ''Cinders'' and ''Hunting Cockroaches,'' is a Polish play wright who lives in New York

results.lead_paragraph: LEAD: A couple of days ago I got a phone call from a successful American movie producer. He was stopping off in New York for one day on his way from Moscow to Malibu, which may be the most heavily traveled traffic route today. My heart jumped; when I had met him before he had mentioned that he might be interested in doing some theater, and I happened to have a play in my desk drawer.
